Award.AwardTitle: UNS:Diffuse Optical and Correlation Tomography for Monitoring of Bone-graft Healing

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1507384
Choe, Regine

The overall goal of this proposal is to develop new and safe imaging methods that use red and infrared light to monitor and image the re-growth of blood vessels in healing bones. These methods are based on diffuse optical tomography (DOT) and diffuse correlation tomography (DCT) as scientific research tools to provide non-invasive, deep-tissue longitudinal monitoring of vascularization of engineered tissues. Tissue engineering is a strategy for using artificial or combinations of natural and artificial materials to assist re-growth of damaged tissues, such as broken bones. The optical methods being developed in this project are based on shining a source of light into the tissue of interest (bone in this case), through the skin, and then analyzing light that is reflected back by the tissues. Techniques that non-invasively monitor and longitudinally assess the vascularization process could significantly accelerate the tissue-engineering field, which will lead to new methods for healing damaged tissues.

Towards this goal, a comprehensive DOT and DCT system will be optimized for monitoring the vascularization of bone grafts. The utility of this approach will be established using well-established murine femoral defect models and bone tissue-engineering strategies. Although there have been various applications of diffuse optical tomographic techniques, their utility in bone-vascularization monitoring, especially in engineered tissue, has never been explored. The proposed research objectives are: (1) Expand an existing optical system into a 3D imaging DOT-DCT system and develop a comprehensive tomography algorithm for longitudinal imaging of murine leg; (2) Compare total hemoglobin concentration from DOT and blood flow from DCT to contrast-enhanced micro-CT and histology and a fluorescent microsphere technique, respectively, using live murine autograft models; (3) Characterize the longitudinal vascular changes due to autografts, devitalized allografts, and allografts with tissue-engineered periosteum using the DOT-DCT system and develop a predictive model for graft healing. Educationally, the proposed research will provide stimulating research topics for graduate and undergraduate students, with opportunities to interact with national and international collaborators in various interdisciplinary fields. The project will also involve educational outreach to underrepresented high school student groups at the University of Rochester.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overall goal of this proposal is to develop new and safe imaging methods that use red and infrared light to monitor and image the re-growth of blood vessels in healing bones. These methods are based on diffuse optical tomography (DOT) and diffuse correlation tomography (DCT) as scientific research tools to provide non-invasive, deep-tissue monitoring of blood vessel re-growth (i.e., revascularization) over time in tissues made by engineering. Tissue engineering is a strategy for using artificial or combinations of natural and artificial materials to improve re-growth of damaged tissues, such as broken bones. The optical methods being developed in this project are based on shining a source of light into the tissue of interest (bone, in this case), through the skin, and then analyzing light that is reflected back by the tissues. While various tissue engineering strategies have been developed, vascularization, i.e., the process of blood vessel growth that is critical for the success of most tissue engineering approaches, is assessed using methods that require sacrifice of animals and sample destruction. Such methods include micro-computed tomography (micro-CT) with lead-based contrast agent and histology. Even minimally invasive techniques, such as magnetic resonance imaging or positron emission tomography, require contrast agents to image the microvasculature, with associated concerns related to variable agent delivery, agent-tissue interactions and high cost. Techniques that assess vascularization non-invasively throughout time could significantly accelerate the tissue engineering field, which will lead to new methods for healing damaged tissues. By providing efficient ways to assess vascularization, this methodology will impact the speed of clinical translation of new tissue engineering technologies, saving time and reducing costs.

Towards this goal, a non-contact DCT system that finds the three-dimensional distribution of blood flow inside the mouse leg was developed. To find the three-dimensional distribution of blood volume and blood oxygen saturation, a non-contact DOT system based on spatial frequency domain imaging (SFDI) technique was developed. The ability to find accurate blood related values of these systems was tested using a series of computer simulation, tissue-mimicking materials with known values, and live mice with a transplanted bone graft in the femur. For blood flow, in particular, our technique was compared with the fluorescent microsphere technique. In this gold standard technique, fluorescent microspheres small enough to be trapped in micro blood vessels are introduced into the mouse circulation, then the tissues are cut into small pieces after animal sacrifice to image the microspheres. The number of microspheres is proportional to blood flow. Our technique produced similar values as the fluorescent microsphere technique. Using the developed DCT system, the blood flow changes in space and time were followed for three different groups of mice with transplanted autografts, allografts with no living cells to prevent an immune system response, and tissue-engineered allografts designed to improve healing. Distinct patterns of blood flow among mice with well healed bones and poorly healed bones were observed. Using biomechanical testing as the measure of bone healing quality, we developed and demonstrated a methodology to build a predictive model for graft healing based on frequent early light measurements. Although there have been various applications of diffuse optical tomographic techniques, their utility in bone vascularization monitoring, especially in engineered tissue, has never been explored. The studies supported by this NSF award are the first of their kind.

Educationally, the proposed research provided stimulating research topics for graduate and undergraduate students along with laboratory technicians. Through this research topic, they had opportunities to interact with national and international collaborators in various interdisciplinary fields. We also developed a new interactive hands-on experimental module to incorporate into educational outreach to underrepresented high school student groups through the summer program run by the David T. Kearns Center for Leadership and Diversity in Arts, Sciences and Engineering at the University of Rochester. Several undergraduate students were involved in the development of the module and education of underrepresented high school students on an example of biomedical optics.
